dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From overhead, we see a Toyota Prius chugging along down highway.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: When you’re the president of the 98th largest financial services company in America you need to project a certain image. An image of boldness, strength and confidence. Suddenly, a brand new, shiny black Porsche Boxster convertible ZOOMS around the Prius, leaving it in the dus As we move in, we see the driver of the Porsche is NICK HENDRICKS. Sunglasses. Top down. Wind in his hair. He looks pretty cool.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: You’re not gonna get that image driving a Prius.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick pulls into the lot and takes a reserved spot near th entrance with a sign that reads “NICK HENDRICKS, PRESIDEN He gets out of the Porsche and removes the dealer’s paper floormat from under the pedals.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I put in a lot of years to become president of Comnindyne and now I’m earning a lot more and working a lot... more. The strange thing is, when I finally made it to the top, I realized that I’d actually only made it to the bottom of the top. Nick heads toward the building, passing several parking s with much more expensive sports cars (Ferrari, Porsche 91 Turbo, Mercedes SLR McLaren) each with a sign bearing a n and the title “PRESIDENT.”

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Turns out Comnidyne has seven presidents. And I’m the most junior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick enters to find his more senior COLLEAGUES in their morning meeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, sorry I’m late. (holding up keys) Had to stop by the dealership to pick up a little something. The others all react, impressed. PETER, 40's, squat, gnom like, heads to the window which looks down at the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Well done. Hendricks got himself some big boy wheels. Another colleague, ARTHUR, 60’s, joins them at the window

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: (looking outside) Which one is she?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (pointing) Right there. She’s the Porsche.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Barely. You got a Boxster?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Uh huh. Two-thousand thirteen. A sallow-looking woman, JEANINE, 50's, chimes in.

dialogues.speaker: JEANINE
dialogues.text: Cost you that much? The others all laugh derisively.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: It’s a great little car.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: That’s adorable. You’re a great little man. GLEN, 50's, hairpiece and jowls, steps up.

dialogues.speaker: GLEN
dialogues.text: I got my daughter a Boxster for her Sweet 16. Made me take it back. Said it was “too girly.” They all laugh again. Nick grits his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Okay. Maybe we should get to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You couldn't at least spring for the Carrera?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Figured I’d go with the classic.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Uh, the Boxster was introduced about forty years after the Carrera. So, not exactly “a classic.”

dialogues.speaker: JEANINE
dialogues.text: (patting him on the shoulder) Don’t worry, Nick. Another ten years here, you'll be able to afford a real car. Nick stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: All right, guys. Looks like the Swiss are about to change their drawdown regs, so we need to talk about a new home for our master feeder fund. The presidents turn back to the piles of paperwork on the table in front of them and resume their dreary work. As t talk, the sound drops down and we PUSH IN on Nick as he stares at his colleagues.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You know what’s at the top of the corporate ladder? Another goddamn ladder. I may be a president, but I'm really just a fucking corporate tool. FREEZE ON Nick’s forlorn expression as the words appear o him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We find KURT BUCKMAN sitting poolside on a chaise lounge, reading US Weekly and sipping a can of beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're probably wondering, “how does this handsome bastard get to sit by the pool with a beer on a workday?” Well, here’s how: you quit your job, find a sugar mama whose rich husband is out of the picture and let her take care of you. He puts the magazine over his face and is about to take a nap.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Kurt! Refill! Kurt sets the magazine aside and springs to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kurt enters, carrying three glasses of mojitos. Sitting o the couch is RHONDA HARKEN and her friends, NIKKI, late 3 a lot of work done, and HEIDI, early 40’s, even more work

dialogues.speaker: KURT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Does it bother me that my sugar mama happens to be the ex-wife of the man who tried to kill me and my friends? Meh.

dialogues.speaker: RHONDA
dialogues.text: (to the girls) She spends thousands on Botox. She should spend 50 cents on a razor for that moustache.

dialogues.speaker: HEIDI
dialogues.text: She looks like Tom Selleck with fake boobs! The girls cackle. Kurt quietly sets the glasses on the coffee table and turns to go.

dialogues.speaker: RHONDA
dialogues.text: Kurt. Really?

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: RHONDA
dialogues.text: The table. It’s African bubinga wood. I’ve told you. Use a coaster.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Right. Sorry.  He puts a coaster under each glass.

dialogues.speaker: RHONDA
dialogues.text: Thank you. (back to the girls) Speaking of Erica, have you seen how fat her husband has gotten?

dialogues.speaker: NIKKI
dialogues.text: Have you seen my tub of shit lately? He’s gained thirty pounds since the holidays.

dialogues.speaker: HEIDI
dialogues.text: (to Rhonda, indicating Kurt) At least you got a good one. Kurt grins, flattered.

dialogues.speaker: RHONDA
dialogues.text: He’s okay. Kurt’s smile fades.

dialogues.speaker: RHONDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Getting a little doughy in the middle.

dialogues.speaker: NIKKI
dialogues.text: I don’t believe it.

dialogues.speaker: RHONDA
dialogues.text: It’s true. (to Kurt) Pop that shirt off. Show them.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: RHONDA
dialogues.text: The shirt. Pop it off.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: I’m not gonna--

dialogues.speaker: RHONDA
dialogues.text: (sternly) Pop it.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Rhonda, I really don’t--

dialogues.speaker: RHONDA
dialogues.text: Pop. It. Off.  Resigned, Kurt takes his shirt off. He’s in pretty good shape.

dialogues.speaker: RHONDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look at that.

dialogues.speaker: HEIDI
dialogues.text: He looks all right to me.

dialogues.speaker: RHONDA
dialogues.text: No, look. She grabs what belly fat Kurt has, pinching and jiggling

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: RHONDA
dialogues.text: How do we get rid of this? Because this is gross. Here, touch it. As the other women begin to poke and prod Kurt’s abdomen, sighs heavily.

dialogues.speaker: KURT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I guess the only real downside of this whole arrangement is that sometimes I feel kinda, I don’t know, bad about myself. Like I've turned into a ball-less little bitch. FREEZE ON Kurt as the words appear over him:

dialogues.speaker: BITCH
dialogues.text: EXT. DALE’S HOUSE - DAY DALE ARBUS opens the front door of his tiny house. His VE pregnant wife, STACY, bids him goodbye. Dale leans in to kiss her, but her enormous belly makes it hard to reach h face.

dialogues.speaker: DALE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It’s all happening. I got married. Stacy’s pregnant-- with triplets! And I finally got my sex offender status expunged. Which is great, because otherwise I’d have to stay 100 yards from my own kids. Dale crosses to his car and pulls out of the driveway.  EXT. DR. SLOCUM’S OFFICE - SHORT TIME LATER Dale pulls into the parking lot, passing a sign that read “DR. HARLEN SLOCUM, PEDIATRIC DENTIST” above an image of cartoon TOOTH having its own tooth pulled by another TOOT dressed as a dentist.

dialogues.speaker: DALE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I quit my dental assistant job and got a new job. As a dental assistant. But for a really sweet man. INT. DR. SLOCUM’S OFFICE HALLWAY - MOMENTS LATER Dale walks down a hallway, passing framed photos of DR. SLOCUM in his dental scrubs at age 35... 45... 55... 75.. 80-something.

dialogues.speaker: DALE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A really sweet, really, really old man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dale enters a world of CHAOS populated by screaming KIDS a handful of exhausted PARENTS. Toys lie strewn everywher A group of TODDLERS tear the upholstery out of a sofa cushion. A RECEPTIONIST sits at a desk, oblivious. Dale takes a step and TRIPS over something off-camera. He looks down and picks up the CRYING INFANT he stumbled on.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Okay, whose baby is this? You can’t just leave your babies on the floor. A harried MOTHER takes the baby from him as he carefully picks his way across the kid-covered floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dale enters to find a 4 YEAR-OLD BOY, GABE, hollering miserably as DR. SLOCUM, 80’s, sits slumped asleep with dental tools still inside Gabe’s open mouth.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Not again. Dale hurries over and nudges the dentist awake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Slocum! Wake up. You're with a patient.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SLOCUM
dialogues.text: (groggy) What?! I know. What?! Dale gently removes the tools from Gabe’s mouth. Gabe sto yelling.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: (to Gabe) You're okay, buddy. (checking) Nothing bleeding here.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: I have to pee.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Okay. Bathroom’s down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Someone has to take me.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Where’s your mommy?

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: She’s at Target.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Oh. Okay, I’ll take you.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SLOCUM
dialogues.text: Hang on. I’ve got to check his lower left cuspid.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: He’s gotta go to the bathroom, doctor.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SLOCUM
dialogues.text: Fine. Dale escorts the boy out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dale leads Gabe to the bathroom door.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Okay. Here you go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to come in and help me.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Help you? What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: You have to unbutton my pants.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: I don’t think that’s a great idea, Gabe.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Please! I have to go! Dale looks around furtively.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Okay, come on. (hustling him inside) Quick, quick, come on. INT. BATHROOM —- CONTINUOUS Dale and Gabe enter. Dale locks the door behind them and starts uncomfortably undoing Gabe’s pants.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: (mumbling) It’s just that I recently had something expunged from my record. It was a big misunderstanding. Empty playground. No kids anywhere. But I really shouldn’t be doing this... He gets the pants open and heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: DALE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay. You’re good to go. I’1l wait outside.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: No! You have to aim for me.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: What?! No one’s taught you how to aim? Gabe shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: DALE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What kind of parenting-- Is your mom always at Target?  10.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: I’m gonna go in my pants!

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: I’m gonna go to jail! Gabe does a desperate pee pee dance.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Please! It hurts!

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Aw man. You’re really gonna make me do this? (sighs) All right. Let’s get it over with. Dale takes a latex glove from his dental scrubs and pulls on his hand. With his arm outstretched and looking the ot way, he helps Gabe aim (off-screen). We hear the sound of peeing.

dialogues.speaker: DALE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There you go. (to himself) This is not a good situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mortified Dale leads Gabe back to the exam room. Dale peels off his glove and tosses it in a bin.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Feel better?

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Yes. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: You’re welcome. (beat) Now, you don’t necessarily have to tell your mom that I helped you pee. It can be our secret. (quickly) Not a secret. Just a fun thing that we never tell anyone else. (quickly) Not a fun thing. Just a secret. INT. DR. SLOCUM’S OFFICE - SHORT TIME LATER Dale peers through the blinds and sees Gabe getting in a with his MOTHER.  11. The car pulls out of its parking spot and drives forward fifty feet or so, then SCREECHES to a halt, SLAMS into reverse and ZOOMS back into the parking lot. Dale looks like he’s going to puke as Gabe’s mother exits car and marches toward the building.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Oh shit oh shit oh shit... He hurries to the waiting room to head her off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dale bursts through the door to find Gabe’s mother walkin to the receptionist.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Let me expl-- GABE’S MOTHER (to Receptionist) I completely forgot to schedule Gabe’s next appointment. Dale lets out an enormous sigh of relief.

dialogues.speaker: DALE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I guess if I’m being honest, this job stresses the crap out of me. I’m not so much a dental assistant as a goddamn babysitter. We FREEZE on Dale’s face as the words appear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick, Kurt and Dale sit at a table with drinks. Like Nick most of the PATRONS wear business attire. Many are older. PIANIST plays soft jazz in one corner.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: (to Dale) What’s the deal with you and little kids’ dicks?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: There weren't “dicks.” It was just one. You make it sound like it was a boys choir!  12.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I don’t know, Dale. I’m starting to see a pattern here. I mean, if I had been on the sex offender registry, I'd try and avoid handling kids’ private parts.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: (to Dale) I don’t think I can be friends with you anymore.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Yeah, feels like two strikes is enough.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: What was I supposed to do? Let the kid piss in his pants?

dialogues.speaker: KURT/NICK
dialogues.text: Yeah./Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: You guys don’t get it. You’re not fathers-to-be. You don’t have the instinct to protect children.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: I have the instinct to protect them from people like you.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Very funny.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: How’s Stacy feeling?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Pregnant. Very pregnant. I don’t think the human body is designed to carry three babies.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Are you grossed out by her body?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: No! Of course not. It’s beautiful. (off their looks) It’s a little gross. She’s got this weird line that runs down her belly.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Yeesh. Not worth it, I say.  13. A WAITER sets down a fresh dish of olives, removing the o dish full of pits. Dale eagerly begins eating the new one

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Dale, that’s your fourth bowl of olives.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: I like olives.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Just because they keep bringing them doesn’t mean you have to keep wolfing them down.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: But I like ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: (to Nick) What do you care?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: It’s embarrassing. This is a classy place.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: It’s a bullshit place. I don’t know why you drag us here all the time.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Yeah, what was wrong with our old bar?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: This is much nicer.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Hotel bars suck. The beer costs ten bucks and the women are either old or hookers I can’t afford.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: And that bathroom attendant expects me to pay him for paper towels, so I can’t even wash my hands. Kurt and Nick grimace as Dale roots through the olive dis

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: (to Nick) I know why you like this place. You’re a fancypants.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: What?  14.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Admit it. Since you became president, you’ve gotten all fancy.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I’m not a fancypants.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Dale?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: (to Nick) You're a little fancy.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Fuck you guys.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Hey, hey. That’s not a very fancy thing to say. (then) It’s just that lately you seem to care a lot more about where you drink, what you wear, what kind of car you drive--

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: How many olives I eat.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Look, when you get to my position, people expect certain things of you.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: But you’re the boss. Doesn’t that Mean you don’t have to care what people think of you anymore?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: It’s more complicated than that.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Hey, as long as it’s making you happy.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Yeah. We stay on NICK. It’s pretty clear that he is not happy. From the hallway outside the bar, they suddenly hear MUSI blaring over a loudspeaker. It’s “I GOTTA FEELING” by The Black Eyed Peas, accompanied by CHEERING from what sounds like a decent-sized crowd.  15.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: What’s going on out there? They exchange a curious look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick, Kurt and Dale open the door find a motivational sem in progress. An audience of around 100 PEOPLE sit in rows seats as the music BOOMS from a PA. On a riser at the fro of the room, an energetic 40-something man claps along to song.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Who is that?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: You don’t know who that is? That’s Denny Paul.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: How do you know him?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: From his sign. Dale points behind them to a sign featuring a headshot of DENNY PAUL beneath the title “YOU DA BOSS!” Denny picks up a mic as the music fades out.

dialogues.speaker: DENNY
dialogues.text: Am I the only one who has a feeling that tonight is gonna be a good, good night?!

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Let's go. Nick and Kurt start to go.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Wait. Let’s see what Denny has to say.

dialogues.speaker: DENNY
dialogues.text: Show of hands. Who here had a vision when they were younger of where they wanted their life to go? Most of the crowd raises their hands.

dialogues.speaker: DENNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay. Now how many of you are living that vision? Who here is living their “vision life”?  16. Only a few hands go up. Denny “scans” the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: DENNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hmm. I don’t see any hands. Oh wait, here’s one. Boom. He puts up his own hand and points at it. Nope.

dialogues.speaker: DENNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s right. This guy with his hand up? You know who he is? He’s me. Just little old me. Living my vision life. Wanna know how I did it?

dialogues.speaker: NICK KURT
dialogues.text: Don’t care.

dialogues.speaker: DENNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I grabbed the reins of the horse that was my life and I slapped that horse's ass and I made it ride where I wanted it to ride. Not down some shitty path that the horse wanted to ride. Because horses are idiots.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: He’s not wrong.

dialogues.speaker: DENNY
dialogues.text: Here’s the deal, gang: the only people who are truly happy in this crazy world are the ones who don’t have to answer to anybody. They’re their own boss. They control their destiny. ANGLE ON Nick and Kurt who are actually listening now.

dialogues.speaker: DENNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: See, I used to be just like you. A drone. No self-respect. Working for the man. Then I realized, I am the man. I quit my job, left my loveless marriage and started my own business... helping other people start their own business. And here’s the kicker, folks. Last year, I made in the very high five figures. Guess what? Vision life. Lovin’ it. Denny drops the mic to the floor. The crowd applauds appreciatively. After a moment, Denny picks up the mic again.  17.

dialogues.speaker: DENNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So let’s get into the fifteen steps. Step one: take a good look at yourself in the mirror, or any reflective surface: a shiny pan, a still puddle-- A HOTEL EMPLOYEE approaches the guys.

dialogues.speaker: HOTEL EMPLOYEE
dialogues.text: Excuse me, gentlemen, can I see your tickets, please? Nick, Kurt and Dale all shake their heads and wander out the ballroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys are back in the bar.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: All I’m saying is, Denny Paul has a point. I thought that when I went to work for Dr. Slocum I’d be happier. But my job still kinda sucks.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I hear you, Dale. I’m not exactly living the dream either.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Seriously? Have you learned nothing? You want to kill your bosses again?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: What? No! I just mean, maybe the problem wasn’t working for our old bosses. Maybe the problem is working for anyone.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: I don’t work for anyone.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: You kinda do.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: (to Kurt) Mrs. Harken treats you like a slave.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: You don’t have sex with a slave.  18.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Thomas Jefferson did.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: (noticing) Hey, look. ANGLE ON Denny Paul drinking a whisky at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: DALE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s Denny Paul. (calling to him) Denny! Mr. Paul! (Denny looks over) Can we buy you a drink? Nick and Kurt grimace. Denny shrugs, downs his drink, signals the bartender for another one, and ambles over to them. He looks fairly drunk.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Buying him a drink.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Doesn't really look like he needs one.

dialogues.speaker: DENNY
dialogues.text: (a bit slurred) What’s up, guys?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: We really enjoyed your seminar--

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: We snuck in.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: And we left after five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: DENNY
dialogues.text: Candor alert! Look out. The Waiter sets down Denny’s drink. He downs it in one gu and gestures for another.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: (sotto to Nick) Alcoholic alert.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Look out.  19.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: I’m Dale. This is Nick and Kurt. We were just talking about how great it would be to be our own bosses.

dialogues.speaker: DENNY
dialogues.text: If talking was doing, a telephone would be a hammer.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Not sure I get that.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: That’s only because it makes no sense.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: How did you do it, Denny? Did you follow your own fifteen steps? Denny looks at them and considers for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: DENNY
dialogues.text: Buy me another drink. Dale signals the waiter.

dialogues.speaker: DENNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (leaning in) You wanna know a secret? The fifteen steps are bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Get out of town.

dialogues.speaker: DENNY
dialogues.text: Yeah. I just made ‘em up. People love steps. And they love being told what to do.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: So, what do we do? Tell us?

dialogues.speaker: DENNY
dialogues.text: You want to know how I started my business? He fumbles for his wallet, taking it out and handing them business card.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (reading) International Venture Partners?  20.

dialogues.speaker: DENNY
dialogues.text: Bingo. Venture capital. These guys set me up with enough cash to get “You Da Boss” off the ground.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: What’s the catch?

dialogues.speaker: DENNY
dialogues.text: No catch. They take a 10 percent ownership stake. They make money when you make money. You just gotta have a good enough idea.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: And “You Da Boss” was a good enough idea?

dialogues.speaker: DENNY
dialogues.text: Did you see that crowd tonight? I’m a very charismatic guy. Denny notices a WOMAN in a pencil skirt walk past.

dialogues.speaker: DENNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Are you a prostitute? The guys look horrified.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: (after a beat) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DENNY
dialogues.text: (getting up) All right, guys. Good luck with... whatever we were talking about. He stumbles off with the prostitute. Kurt and Nick watch go, incredulous. Dale stares at the business card.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Hmm. A lot to think about. INT. HARKEN’S HOUSE - LATER Nick, Kurt and Dale enter from the front door.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Keep your voices down. I don’t want to wake her.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: It’s past your curfew, isn’t it?  They head Relieved, 21.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: You want to get smacked?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: (quietly) No. into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (looking around nervously) Does she still have that cat?

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: No. He ran away months ago.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Good. Nick sits on the sofa. As he does, a CAT leaps onto his shoulder from behind with a YOWL and darts away.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What the hell?! You said he ran away.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: That’s the new cat.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: What, does she rescue them from a haunted house? Kurt pours drinks from a wet bar and they all sit. Dale s his drink on the table.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Dale! Use a coaster. That’s bubinga wood.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (to Kurt) Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: (holding up business card) I think we should seriously consider this venture capital thing.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: They don’t just hand you money, Dale. You need to pitch them a good business idea.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Like an invention?  22.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Could be.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: I’ve got a ton of ideas for inventions.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (dubious) Do you?

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: You know how your dick sticks to your balls when it’s hot out?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Um...

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Picture this: underwear with compartments that separate your dick from your balls.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: No one’s gonna fund that.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: When it’s hot out, they will. We'll just pitch it on a hot day.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: That's a stupid idea. (beat) It should be a non-stick spray for your balls, like Pam.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Much better.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Wait, wait, I got one. Regular sized condoms that are packaged in Magnum condom wrappers. So the girl you're with thinks you’ve got a big dick.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Ooh, that just gave me an idea. A condom in a spray can. It goes on as a liquid, and then it hardens into a solid.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: You're just taking my ideas and putting them in spray cans. (then) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: KURT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And how are you supposed to remove the rubber after it’s fused onto your penis?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: It’ll come with an antidote spray. Some kind of acid. That’s for our lab guys to figure out.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (to Dale and Kurt) Why do all of your inventions have to do with dicks and balls?

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Why were all of the Wright Brothers’ ideas about planes?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Maybe Nick’s right. Maybe we need to focus more on vagina inventions.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: No, the key to a good invention is that it solves some everyday problem. They sit there and think for a minute.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Okay, here’s an everyday problem: showering. You gotta shampoo, condition, lather up, rinse, repeat. It takes forever. There’s a beat.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: So what’s the invention?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I thought we were just talking about problems.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I think I’m gonna go to bed.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: One sec. Dummy may be onto something. It does seem like showering is pretty inefficient.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Right? I bet the average person loses a day every week just showering.  24.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (re: Dale’s math) Feels wrong.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: What if there was some kind of a showerhead that you fill with soap, shampoo and conditioner and it mixes it with the water?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Yeah! You could turn a dial to choose what you want it to spray. Like those Miracle-Gro things you attach to a garden hose.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Right. They turn to Nick for his reaction.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: It’s... not terrible. But I’m sure it already exists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys stand around a laptop computer. On the screen is Google search for “showerhead with built-in soap.”

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Not finding it.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Try Bed, Bath & Beyond. They’ve got everything. Kurt does.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: So, should we call that venture capital guy?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: It’s 2 in the morning, Dale. And you don’t have a prototype or even a name for this thing.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: How about... the Shower Buddy?  25.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: That sounds like a gay friend who soaps up your back in the shower.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: I don’t know why you go right to “gay.” (types on laptop) Let’s see what comes up under “Shower Buddy.” They all cringe and recoil at what appears on screen.

dialogues.speaker: DALE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay, that’s pretty gay. But it’s not a product.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: It’s more of a... position. Rhonda enters in a bathrobe.

dialogues.speaker: RHONDA
dialogues.text: What’s going on in here? Kurt hastily slams the laptop shut on Dale’s hand. She shuts

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Ow!

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Just hanging out with the guys, hon.

dialogues.speaker: RHONDA
dialogues.text: Do you know what time it is? Some of us have to work in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: (under his breath) You don’t work.

dialogues.speaker: RHONDA
dialogues.text: I’ve got yoga at ten. And I don’t appreciate the attitude. It’s time to say goodnight to your friends.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: But-- him down with a look.

dialogues.speaker: KURT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Nick and Kurt) You guys better go.  26.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: What about our Shower Buddy? Rhonda looks confused. Kurt herds Nick and Dale toward th door.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Forget it, Dale. It’s silly.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: I don’t think it’s silly. I think it could be the key to our vision life.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Kurt. Rhonda. Nick and Dale exit. Rhonda heads for the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: RHONDA
dialogues.text: Let’s go. Upstairs. My pussy’s not going to eat itself. Kurt sighs, then slumps out after her. MUSIC CUE: “Modern Man” by Arcade Fire

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick walks to his Boxster and stops abruptly when he sees BUMPER STICKER has been stuck to his rear bumper that rea “My Other Car is a Porsche” Nick tries to peel it off, but only part of the top layer comes off. Pissed, he looks around and notices his fellow PRESIDENTS watching from a window and laughing their asse off at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kurt stands at the checkout counter as a CUTE FEMALE CASH rings up his purchases. He gives her a flirty smile which she returns... until she sees what he’s buying: Secret deodorant, Oil of Olay, and an enormous value pack of tampons. He hands her a credit card. INSERT the card: it belong to Rhonda Harken and has her photo on it. The cashier looks at him dubiously. Kurt shrugs sheepishl  27. INT. DR. SLOCUM’S EXAM ROOM - DAY Dale sits on his stool making detailed, yet crudely drawn sketches on a steno pad of the proposed “Shower Buddy” device. He smiles, pleased, then looks up to see Dr. Sloc has fallen asleep and the dental chair is empty. He looks around frantically and gasps when he spots the PATIENT, a five year-old girl, who has climbed halfway ou the window. Dale hurries over to rescue her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dale’s car pulls up to a sleek, modern building. INT. DALE'S CAR —- CONTINUOUS Dale wears a slightly tattered business suit. He takes ou of his pocket the International Venture Partners card tha Denny Paul gave them and double checks the address. INT. MR. NAGOPIAN’S OFFICE - LATER Dale sits on a couch in a well-appointed office and finis his pitch to someone offscreen. Beside him stands an ease with his Shower Buddy sketch tacked to it.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: The Shower Buddy eliminates the endless cycle of washing and rinsing and washing and rinsing. It’s not just a time saver. It’s a life saver. My team is ready to move on this with or without your help. But the only way we can do that is with your help. REVERSE ON ALEX NAGOPIAN, 40's, well dressed, confident a slightly intimidating (think Liam Neeson). Beside him sit JOYCE, 30's, an attractive colleague. Nagopian considers Dale's pitch for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: MR. NAGOPIAN
dialogues.text: You're a funny little man, Dale.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Go on.

dialogues.speaker: MR. NAGOPIAN
dialogues.text: As far as your idea, this “Shower Buddy”? (beat) I love it.  28.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Seriously?!

dialogues.speaker: MR. NAGOPIAN
dialogues.text: Yes. It’s smart, it fills a niche. What do you think, Joyce?

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Sounds like the kind of product we like to fund.

dialogues.speaker: MR. NAGOPIAN
dialogues.text: Of course, our due diligence people will have to make sure no one else has done it.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Well, we googled it and didn’t find anything.

dialogues.speaker: MR. NAGOPIAN
dialogues.text: I see. And why aren’t your partners here with you?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: They’re very busy men. We all are. Very busy. Men.

dialogues.speaker: MR. NAGOPIAN
dialogues.text: But you have power of attorney to sign on their behalf? Dale stares at him for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: ...yes. (then) Does this mean we’re in business?

dialogues.speaker: MR. NAGOPIAN
dialogues.text: That depends. How much do you need to get the Shower Buddy off the ground?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Do you have a piece of paper?

dialogues.speaker: MR. NAGOPIAN
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: So I can write down the amount and slide it across the table to you. Nagopian looks mildly annoyed. He nods to Joyce, who tear piece of paper off a pad and hands it to Dale.  29.

dialogues.speaker: DALE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Great. Thanks. I’ve always wanted to do this. Dale scribbles on the paper and slides it across the coff table. Nagopian looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: MR. NAGOPIAN
dialogues.text: I can’t read this. Is this a “2"?

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: (leaning in) Looks like a “G.”

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: No, that’s a “9.”

dialogues.speaker: MR. NAGOPIAN
dialogues.text: Then I don’t understand this number. You have two commas next to each other.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: No, no, that’s not a comma. That’s also a nine-- you know what? Let me write it again--

dialogues.speaker: MR. NAGOPIAN
dialogues.text: Why don’t you just say the number?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: (tentatively) Nine hundred ninety-nine thousand, nine-hundred, ninety nine dollars?

dialogues.speaker: MR. NAGOPIAN
dialogues.text: Why not an even million?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: It sounds like less?

dialogues.speaker: MR. NAGOPIAN
dialogues.text: This isn’t the Radio Shack. A million is fine.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: (floored) Fuck me. (then, covering) Wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: MR. NAGOPIAN
dialogues.text: Joyce here will bring you to our legal department to sign the necessary paperwork. Nagopian stands and shakes Dale’s hand.  30.

dialogues.speaker: MR. NAGOPIAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Congratulations, Dale. We look forward to a long and profitable relationship with you and your Shower Buddy. (beat) That name? Is it a little gay?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: MR. NAGOPIAN
dialogues.text: Fair enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dale sits at a desk in another room as Joyce places a lar stack of documents in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: All you have to do is sign on the last page for you and your partners.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Not so fast. If there’s one thing I know about business: you never sign anything without reading it carefully.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Take your time. She sits down as Dale begins to read the first page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two pages into the stack, Dale is BORED OUT OF HIS MIND a fighting to stay awake.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Okay, this all looks good. He flips to the last page and in an INSERT we see him sig first his own name, then forge the signatures of “Nick Hendricks” and “Kurt Buckman.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick, dressed for work, joins Dale, still in his suit, an Kurt at an outdoor table.  31.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I have fifteen minutes, Dale. I never do lunch outside the office. What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: He wouldn’t tell me anything till you got here.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: This isn’t something I could tell you over the phone.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Why are you wearing your church clothes? Kurt and Nick exchange a grave look.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Is it your unborn babies?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Oh, Dale. I’m so sorry. How’s Stacy doing?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: She's fine! The babies are fine! Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Well, why did you scare us like that?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: I didn’t scare anybody! You're scaring me.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: So you dragged us out here to tell us your babies are fine?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: No! This has nothing to do with my babies! You’re ruining this!

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Ruining what?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: This! He pulls a check from his jacket pocket and gingerly hold up for them to see. INSERT CHECK in the amount of ONE MILLION DOLLARS made ou Nick Hendricks, Kurt Buckman and Dale Arbus.  32.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: What-- what are we looking at here, Dale?

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Is that one of those Publishers Clearinghouse checks?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: No. It’s a real check. From the venture capital place Denny Paul used. I pitched them the Shower Buddy and they loved it!

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: They loved the Shower Buddy?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: They said it filled a niche.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Let me see that. He grabs the check and examines it.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Why would you do this without telling us?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Because I knew you didn’t believe in the Buddy like I did. Nick gets up.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Where are you going? Nick points across the street at a bank.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I’m gonna see if this thing is real. Dale scurries after him. Kurt grabs his burger and follow INT. BANK —- MINUTES LATER Nick, Kurt and Dale huddle around the window of a BANK TE who types the check information into her computer. After beat,  33.

dialogues.speaker: BANK TELLER
dialogues.text: Would you like this deposited to separate or joint accounts?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: So it’s real?

dialogues.speaker: BANK TELLER
dialogues.text: Um, yes it is.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Fuck me.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Told you!

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (to Teller) Can I have that back, please? Nick takes the check and the three move away.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Dale) You need to return this.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Whoa, whoa. Hang on.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: No one hands you a million dollars without there being a catch. This is too good to be true.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: What if it’s too good to be not true? Shouldn’t we at least consider it?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (checks watch) I’m going to be late for work. He turns to go but Kurt stops him.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: So what? So you’re late for work. You're late for being miserable.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I'm sorry?  34.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: You hate working at that place. You've always hated it. Why keep doing something that makes you unhappy?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Yeah, Nick. This could be a whole new start.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: If I quit, the ten years of hard work I put in at Comndiyne will have been for nothing.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: It was always for nothing. What do you think is going to happen? On your death bed, Mr. Comnidyne’s gonna come in, thank you for giving up your entire life and escort you to corporate heaven?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: There is no Mr. Comnidyne.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: No shit. People who work at those places do it because they’re too afraid to do something better.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Touché.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: This coming from the guy who lives with a woman who treats him like a sex butler.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Touché.

dialogues.speaker: NICK KURT
dialogues.text: (to Dale) (to Dale) Stop it. Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: (to Nick) You know what? You’re right. I’m gonna leave Rhonda. Dale and I have a business to start.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: That’s what’s up! He high-fives Kurt.  35.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Come on, Nick. (holding up the million dollar check) Life doesn’t give you a lot of opportunities like this. But do what you gotta do. Off Nick’s ambivalence,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Having returned to work, Nick joins his colleagues for another board meeting.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Hey, where’s Arthur?

dialogues.speaker: JEANINE
dialogues.text: You didn’t hear? He had another heart attack this morning.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Is he okay?

dialogues.speaker: GLEN
dialogues.text: It’s his third. I’m sure he’s used to them by now. They chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Should we send him something?

dialogues.speaker: JEANINE
dialogues.text: What do you get the guy who has everything... wrong with his heart. Everyone but Nick laughs again.

dialogues.speaker: GLEN
dialogues.text: Let’s get him something small and cheap.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: How about Nick’s Boxster? They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I quit. They all look at him for a beat. Is he joking?

dialogues.speaker: JEANINE
dialogues.text: What?  36.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Yeah. I can’t do this anymore. He starts to gather his things in his briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: With all due respect, guys, I just don’t respect any of you. And I really don’t want to turn into you. He suddenly stops loading his case.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What am I doing? I don’t need any of this. I’ve got my Shower Buddy now. See ya. He dumps the files out, shuts his case and exits. There’s stunned silence, then

dialogues.speaker: GLEN
dialogues.text: “Shower buddy”?

dialogues.speaker: JEANINE
dialogues.text: Did he just come out of the closet?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: That explains the Boxster. INT. DR. SLOCUM’S OFFICE - SAME TIME Dale sits across a desk from Dr. Slocum.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: ...it’s nothing personal. You’re a very nice man and I appreciate you hiring me, but it’s time for me to take another direction with my career. Now, I realize you're fast asleep... REVERSE ANGLE to reveal Slocum is, in fact, fast asleep a his desk.

dialogues.speaker: DALE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .--but I wanted to tell you in person anyway. So... (getting up) -+-guess I’m just gonna... go. He quietly opens the door to the office, but it stops halfway, banging into something in the hall.

dialogues.speaker: SFX
dialogues.text: Dale reaches down and picks up another unhappy BABY.  37.

dialogues.speaker: DALE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (calling out to the waiting room) What did I say about leaving babies on the floor?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rhonda, Nikki and Heidi lounge by the pool.

dialogues.speaker: RHONDA
dialogues.text: So I had to fire Monica.

dialogues.speaker: NIKKI
dialogues.text: I thought you liked her.

dialogues.speaker: RHONDA
dialogues.text: I did. But I saw “The Help” and it just felt racist to have a black cleaning lady. From inside we hear the sound of something being dragged across the floor.

dialogues.speaker: RHONDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you know any white cleaning ladies?

dialogues.speaker: HEIDI
dialogues.text: Wait, you’re firing your black cleaning lady and replacing her with a white one because you don’t want to feel racist?

dialogues.speaker: RHONDA
dialogues.text: (matter of fact) Uh huh. The dragging sound gets louder and the women look up to s the BUBINGA WOOD COFFEE TABLE emerge from the house, bein shoved outside by Kurt.

dialogues.speaker: RHONDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What the hell? Kurt, what are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: (grunting from effort) I thought of a great spot for this bubinga wood table. He gives the table a final push RIGHT INTO THE POOL. The water splashes Rhonda and her friends who gasp in disbeli

dialogues.speaker: RHONDA
dialogues.text: Are you insane?!  38.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: That's right. I’m sorry. I forgot the coaster. He takes a coaster from his pocket and tosses it into the pool.

dialogues.speaker: KURT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (nodding to Nikki and Heidi) Ladies. And with that, Kurt turns, smiles and goes. MUSIC CUE: “Move On Up” by Curtis Mayfield

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick, Kurt and Dale stand with a REALTOR in the large, em space. Looking pleased, Nick and Kurt shake the Realtor’s hand. Dale goes in for a hug. The Realtor looks uncomfortable. We go into a TIME LAPSE sequence as the warehouse is transformed into a production/office space with manufactu equipment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys watch as a WORKER on a cherrypicker installs a s that reads NICKURDALE INDUSTRIES -- Home of the “Shower Buddy"! Nick and Kurt shake hands. Dale goes in for a hug

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three guys stand with a LAB TECH observing a male TES SUBJECT in a bathing suit trying out prototypes of the Sh Buddy in a glass shower stall. QUICK SERIES OF POPS as the prototypes malfunction: -- The pressure builds up in the shower head and bursts i the subject’s face. -- The subject, now a bit more nervous, turns on the wate and nothing but soap oozes from the shower head. -- The shower head sprays the perfect combination of wate and soap. Our guys look pleased until the shower head inexplicably stops spraying. The subject cautiously inspe the device and suddenly the shower head bursts in his fac again.  39. -- Our guys follow the bruised and pissed off subject to car, apologizing profusely. They manage to convince him t go back into the building. -- Fearing for his life, the same subject gingerly turns the shower which has a new model Shower Buddy installed. This time it actually works as it should. Nick and Kurt h five. In the test chamber we see Dale yank open the showe stall and hug the subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys shake hands and say goodbye to a SEXY YOUNG WOMA they've just finished interviewing. She hands over her resumé and goes. Nick and Dale shake their heads, unimpressed. Kurt, on the other hand, gives them an enthusiastic thumbs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys shake hands and say goodbye to an average-lookin MIDDLE AGED WOMAN they’ve just finished interviewing. Nic and Dale nod approvingly. Kurt gives them a thumbs down a tears up her resumé.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys shake hands and say goodbye to an EXTREMELY HAND MAN they’ve just finished interviewing. The guys all look each other self-consciously. No one is sure how to react.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys stand at the end of a production line manned by about a dozen WORKERS as the very first consumer-ready Sh Buddy rolls off the line. Nick, Kurt and Dale proudly hol the device up as a PHOTOGRAPH is taken. FREEZE on the image. PULL BACK to see the picture is on t cover of “FORTUNE” Magazine. Then PULL BACK further to se the cover is on Dale’s laptop screen. Dale is showing Nic and Kurt what he Photoshopped. He gives them a look: “wouldn't that be cool?” They shake their heads at him.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GOLF COURSE
dialogues.text: The guys smoke cigars as they cruise down the fairway in golf cart, enjoying a mid-week outing. In QUICK POPS we see Nick, Kurt and Dale each tee off.  40. Then three more QUICK POPS as each tries to recover their ball, still smoking their cigars: Nick uses his club to try and knock his ball down from a where it’s wedged. Nick and Dale hold onto Kurt’s belt as he leans over a po searching for his ball. Dale knocks on the door of a house. A pissed off GUY open the door and hands him his golf ball. WIDEN to reveal a g ball-sized hole in one window of the house. Dale smiles sheepishly, takes the ball and hurries away. INT. KURT’S LOFT - DAY Kurt shows Nick and Dale around his new apartment. Moving boxes are scattered around, but it’s a cool pad. A DOG follows them around. Just then, the Sexy Young Woman they interviewed comes out of the bedroom in one of Kurt’s shi Nick and Dale give Kurt a disapproving look. EXT. DALE’S HOUSE - DAY Covering Stacy’s eyes, Dale leads her outside to surprise with a brand new minivan wrapped in a bow in the driveway He presses a button on the remote and the side door opens revealing two car seats installed in the back seat and on the front passenger seat. Stacy kisses him... then points the car seat in the front and shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON our three guys toasting themselves with glasses champagne on the deck of a rented 40-foot sailboat. Wind their hair, white linen pants, etc. Suddenly, they are violently jolted to the side. PULL BACK to show their boat is in the harbor and has DRI sideways into another docked sailboat. Their sails are in disarray-- clearly none of them knows the first thing abo sailing. Panicked, Dale begins winching a line which only TEARS the mainsail down the middle. Kurt and Nick step on the dock and head off, leaving Dale to deal with the mess

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys sit with GREG and NANCY, the handsome guy and mi aged woman they interviewed earlier.  41.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Nancy, how we doing on our production quota?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Solid. We’ve got five thousand units in inventory.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Good. Greg, how are things on the marketing front?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: I’m talking to my contacts at QVC, HSN and Amazon. There’s a lot of interest.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Nice. Dale, can I get a refill? Nick holds up his empty coffee mug.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: You bet! Dale crosses to a coffee pot and refills Nick’s cup.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Kurt, how are sales?

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Well, we haven’t sold a single unit yet, so sales are... non-existent. But here’s the thing: it takes time to build awareness. The only thing standing between us and a multi- million dollar success story is one giant distributor. Like, say, SkyMall. Kurt slaps a SkyMall catalogue down on the table.

dialogues.speaker: KURT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maybe you've heard of it. Reaches six hundred fifty million airline passengers a year.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Yeah? So? Did you call them or something?

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Nope. They called us. They’re interested in the Shower Buddy and want to meet with us later today about putting it in their fall catalogue.  42.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Booyah!

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: That’s great news.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: It’s better than great. Skymall made household names out of the Marshmallow Shooter, the Old Time Popcorn Cart, the Pet Ramp. They put the “world’s largest wall map” on the map!

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Stacy and I got one of those Pet Ramps for Darvis when he couldn't jump onto the bed anymore.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: That dog reeks of shit. You let him in your bed?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Of course. We love Darvis.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: If you love him, why don’t you give him a bath once in a while?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Dogs don’t need baths. They’re self-cleaning.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: That’s cats.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Ugh. I hate the smell of cats. ANGLE ON Greg and Nancy, who exchange a look that says, “ the hell are we working for?”

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (to Greg and Nancy) Sorry. (then) If the Skymall people are coming, we've got to get ready for that pitch. I’11 work up a presentation. Kurt, why don’t you set up the demo in here? Dale, we're gonna need a lot more coffee.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: I’m on it.  43. We follow Nick as he heads out into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick crosses a second floor walkway that overlooks the mo assembly line below. He passes an UNDERLING.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Hey, Tim. Did you get that shipment in yet?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Yep. A bunch of pens and stress reliever balls with the company name on it.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Perfect. Keep up the good work. Nick heads into an office with a sign on the door that re “NICK HENDRICKS, CO-CEO”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick crosses to his desk, but before he gets there he’s startled by a voice.

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Nice suit. Nick whirls around to see Mr. Nagopian sitting on the sof Off to the side stands a LARGE MAN in a suit.

dialogues.speaker: MR. NAGOPIAN
dialogues.text: You’re much better dressed than your “co-CEO” Dale.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Thank you. And you are...?

dialogues.speaker: MR. NAGOPIAN
dialogues.text: Alex Nagopian. International Venture Partners. He stands and shakes Nick’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Oh. Right. It’s nice to finally meet you. Nick nods at the big guy in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: MR. NAGOPIAN
dialogues.text: This is my associate, Ghoukas.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Hi... Ghoukas. (then, to Nagopian) Thank you for believing in what we're doing here.

dialogues.speaker: MR. NAGOPIAN
dialogues.text: Believing is my business. And how is business?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: So far, so good. We've got a big pitch lined up. Could be great for-

dialogues.speaker: MR. NAGOPIAN
dialogues.text: Good, good. Well, we’re not here to get in the way. We just came by to remind you that your repayment is due tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Re-what, now?

dialogues.speaker: MR. NAGOPIAN
dialogues.text: Your repayment. Didn’t Dale explain to you the terms of our loan?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Loan? You made a capital investment. Didn’t you take a ten percent stake in the company?

dialogues.speaker: MR. NAGOPIAN
dialogues.text: Why would I want ten percent of “the Shower Friend?”

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Shower Buddy.

dialogues.speaker: MR. NAGOPIAN
dialogues.text: Friend, Buddy. It’s a stupid idea.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Then why did you invest in it?

dialogues.speaker: MR. NAGOPIAN
dialogues.text: I didn’t. I simply loaned you and your friends a million dollars for a month. And tomorrow, you owe me two million dollars.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I think there’s been a misunderstanding-- (pushing his intercom) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jennifer, can you get Dale and Kurt in here, please?

dialogues.speaker: MR. NAGOPIAN
dialogues.text: It’s all in the paperwork Dale signed on your behalf.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: So what is this? Some kind of scam?

dialogues.speaker: MR. NAGOPIAN
dialogues.text: A scam? No one forced you to borrow a million dollars from us.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: There’s no way we can make a payment like that by tomorrow. The money you gave us is all invested in the company.

dialogues.speaker: MR. NAGOPIAN
dialogues.text: In that case, I wouldn’t be surprised if something unpleasant happened to you and your friends.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Are you threatening us?

dialogues.speaker: MR. NAGOPIAN
dialogues.text: Of course not. I’ve just noticed that the people who fail to repay me tend to have accidents. And strangely, Ghoukas is often the one who finds them.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: That’s a threat!

dialogues.speaker: MR. NAGOPIAN
dialogues.text: It’s not. Have some sympathy for poor Ghoukas. He’s the one who’s always finding these horribly disfigured bodies.

dialogues.speaker: GHOUKAS
dialogues.text: I kill them.

dialogues.speaker: MR. NAGOPIAN
dialogues.text: Ghoukas! We’re doing a conceit. Ghoukas shrugs.  46.

dialogues.speaker: MR. NAGOPIAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All I’m saying is, if you fail to repay me by tomorrow, something terrible may or may not happen to you and your friends.

dialogues.speaker: GHOUKAS
dialogues.text: I'll kill you.

dialogues.speaker: MR. NAGOPIAN
dialogues.text: Ghoukas!

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: All right, you know what? This is the stupidest shakedown ever. If we die, how are we going to pay you back?

dialogues.speaker: MR. NAGOPIAN
dialogues.text: From the life insurance policies Dale signed.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: He didn’t say anything about life insurance policies.

dialogues.speaker: MR. NAGOPIAN
dialogues.text: That's probably because he didn’t read them.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Fuuuuck.

dialogues.speaker: MR. NAGOPIAN
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, Nick. One way or the other, I’ll get my money. He pats Nick on the cheek and starts to exit. Ghoukas hea out right on his heels.

dialogues.speaker: MR. NAGOPIAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ghoukas, please. You don’t have to walk that close. Ghoukas stops walking. Nagopian exits. Ghoukas stands there, unsure what to do.

dialogues.speaker: MR. NAGOPIAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Now you’re too far! Ghoukas heads out. Nick slumps in his chair and distractedly grabs a Nickurd stress reliever ball. He squeezes the hell out of it for beat. Dale and Kurt enter.  47.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Hey, was that Mr. Nagopian I saw leaving? Why wouldn’t he say hi? That’s weird-- In the blink of an eye, Nick grabs Dale and slaps him acr the face.

dialogues.speaker: DALE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ow!

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: You fucking idiot! Kurt steps between them.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Hey, hey. What’s all this? Nick reaches past Kurt and smacks Dale again.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Ow!

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: You killed us! We’re all dead thanks to you!

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: What did I do?!

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: What did he do?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Nagopian? That “venture capital” guy he got our money from? He’s nothing but a loanshark! Dale signed papers saying that tomorrow we owe him two million bucks backed up with life insurance policies. If we don’t pay, we die. Kurt turns to Dale and looks at him for a moment. Then he also smacks him across the face.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Ow! Nick slaps Dale again.

dialogues.speaker: DALE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Stop it! How was I supposed to know? There was so much to read!

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: You goddamn moron.  48.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I knew I shouldn’t have listened to you guys. I gave up my career for this.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: You're worried about your career? What about our lives? Did this Nagopian actually threaten you?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Basically. Ghoukas definitely did.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: What’s a Ghoukas?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: We should go to the cops.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: And tell them what? That Nagopian handed us perfectly legal loan documents which you forged our signatures on? All that does is send you to prison.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: It does?

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: I’m fine with that.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Hang on.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I’m fine with it, too. But as far as Nagopian’s concerned, we still stole a million dollars from him. You don’t think Ghoukas is going to kill us?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: What’s a Ghoukas?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (to Kurt) If we liquidated everything right now, how much cash would we have?

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: About three hundred grand.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: That means we have three days to come up with 1.7 million dollars.  49.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: So, basically, we're riding a cat without a candle.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: What? What is that?

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: It’s a saying. It means we're fucked.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: I think I’ve heard that.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: No, you haven't.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: It’s a common expression. It’s from the olden days.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: It’s from the no days. Why would you ride a cat? And why would a candle help?

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I didn’t come up with it.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I think you did.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Guys, please. The longer we fight, the more we're riding a cat without a candle! Nick’s assistant, JENNIFER, pops her head in. She goes.

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER
dialogues.text: Guys? The SkyMall people said they’re on their way.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Shit, that’s right!

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Hang on. This could be a good thing. If we sell these guys on the Buddy, we could get enough up- front money to pay off Nagopian.  50.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: So, we've just gotta nail this pitch.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Or we die. No pressure. The guys exchange tense looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick, Kurt and Dale are mid-pitch. They look FRAZZLED and SWEATY as they stand across from two seated SkyMall reps, and CLAIRE, 40's. Behind the guys is a large schematic drawing on an easel along with a PORTABLE SHOWER STALL with a Shower Buddy attached.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: (rapid-fire, manic) ...there’s a reason everybody hates showers because it takes so long and the average person wastes one week every month taking showers--

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Well, maybe not a week--

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: It’s all the soaping up and the rinsing off and the shampooing and the rinsing off and the conditioning and the rinsing off--

dialogues.speaker: KURT NICK
dialogues.text: What Dale is trying to say Dale means that we waste a is, the Shower Buddy lot of time showering and the eliminates the wasted time Shower Buddy helps to and streamlines your shower streamline that process. process.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Sounds great. How does it work?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: That’s an excellent question, Claire.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Great question.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Really good.  51. There’s an awkward silence.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: .---So, how does it work?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Right-- (to Kurt) You wanna get her in here? Kurt hurries out.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We thought the best way to show you how the Shower Buddy works is to show... you... how the Shower Buddy works. Dale crosses to the shower stall and begins fiddling with portable water pump attached to a tank. Kurt ushers in a 20-something model, BROOKE, in a bathrob

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: (to Brooke) Hurry, hurry. (to Dan and Claire) This is Brooke. She’s gonna demonstrate the Shower Buddy for you by taking a shower. Brooke? Brooke drops her robe. She’s in a bikini.

dialogues.speaker: KURT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorry, Dan. I know you were hoping she was naked under there. (to Claire) Don’t tell his wife.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I am his wife.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: (covering) I know. Husband and wife. Working together. You’re like Lucy and Desi. Only at SkyMall. Nice.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: (to himself) This fucking pump... Brooke steps into the stall.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: How we doin’, Dale?  52.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: I think there’s something wrong with the motor on this pump. But I can do it by hand. No biggie.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: (nudging Claire and Dan) Our next invention’s gonna be a better water pump. Right, husband and wife? Dale kneels beside the stall and begins rhythmically jerk the water pump.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Might take a second here to get the flow going... Brooke stands awkwardly in the dry shower.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (to Claire and Dan) Shouldn’t be long.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: (pumping away) Getting close. Almost there. There’s an uncomfortable beat as they all watch Dale. There’s no getting around how much it looks like he’s jer off on his knees beside a woman in a shower.

dialogues.speaker: DALE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Close your eyes, Brooke. Here it comes! Just then, a GOB OF LIQUID SOAP dribbles out of the Showe Buddy, landing on Brooke’s face.

dialogues.speaker: DALE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yes! The model does her best to work with the limited amount o water dribbling on her. She spreads the soap on her chest

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: (whispering to Nick) Kinda looks like--

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (sotto) I know. (then) Dale, can we get any more water pressure here?  53.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: (winded) I’m pumping as hard as I can!

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: All right, let me help. Kurt joins Dale and the two of them begin working the pum together.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (to Dan and Claire) Okay, well, obviously, this isn’t the best demonstration. With normal water pressure, there’s a steady stream of soap delivered--

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Ow! It got in my eyes!

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Twist the nozzle to “rinse.”

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I can’t see. She fumbles with the showerhead.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: All right, let me help you. Nick reaches into the stall and tries to adjust the showerhead.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ugh, it got in my mouth. Creamy soap runs down his and Brooke’s arms, as Dale and Kurt, on their knees and dripping with flop sweat, contin to pump away. ANGLE ON DAN and CLAIRE who look appalled.

dialogues.speaker: DALE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Not so hard, Kurt, you’re hurting me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drenched and disheveled from the demonstration, the guys goodbye as Dan and Claire’s car drives away.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Goodbye!  There’s a They give 54.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Take care now! beat.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: So, when do you think we’ll find out? him a withering look.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: That was awful. It felt like we were fucking each other for crack.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I’m covered in soap, but I feel so dirty. (then) That goddamned Shower Buddy.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Don’t blame the Buddy. The Buddy works. It just needed to be ina real shower.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Well, that was our only shot.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: (to Dale) You know, none of this would’ve happened if you hadn’t bought that dipshit Denny Paul a drink.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. How come Denny didn’t get killed? He borrowed from Nagopian too.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: And why would he refer us to him if he knew he was a loan shark?

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Let’s call that fucker and find out. INT. KURT’S OFFICE - MINUTES LATER The guys sit around Kurt’s desk. Denny Paul is on the speaker phone.

dialogues.speaker: DENNY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: How did you find me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You’re in the phone book. 55.

dialogues.speaker: WITH
dialogues.text: INT. DENNY PAUL’S HOUSE —- CONTINUOUS Denny wears no pants. Just a long “You Da Boss” T-shirt. looks haggard.

dialogues.speaker: DENNY
dialogues.text: Shit! Fucking phone book. (then) Under what name?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Your name.

dialogues.speaker: DENNY
dialogues.text: Fuck! I didn’t think you would find me.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: You’re also on Facebook.

dialogues.speaker: DENNY
dialogues.text: Fucking Facebook! I thought I was off the grid.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: You want to tell us why you hooked us up with a loan shark?!

dialogues.speaker: DENNY
dialogues.text: Is this a secure line? The guys look at each other. Huh?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I don’t know. What’s the difference?

dialogues.speaker: DENNY
dialogues.text: They could be listening.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: DENNY
dialogues.text: I can’t say unless it’s a secure line.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Okay, it’s a secure line.  56.

dialogues.speaker: DENNY
dialogues.text: All right. Look, Nagopian is a loan shark--

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: We know that!

dialogues.speaker: DENNY
dialogues.text: I've barely been making my payments. Every dime I earn goes straight to him. I thought if I brought him some fresh meat he'd cut me some slack.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Fresh meat?

dialogues.speaker: DENNY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry I dragged you into this. But hey, maybe if we work together, we can fix it.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: DENNY
dialogues.text: Neither of us alone has enough evidence against these guys, but if we combine what we know, I bet we can figure out a way to turn the tables on Nagopian.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: DENNY
dialogues.text: Leave that to me. Come on over to my place. The address is--

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: We have it. It’s on your Facebook page.

dialogues.speaker: DENNY
dialogues.text: Fuck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kurt pulls his car up to a suburban house. Nick is in the passenger seat, Dale in back.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Here it is. They exit the car. Kurt notices Dale is carrying a grocer bag.  57.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: What is that?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: I brought humus in case we get hungry.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Just humus? No chips?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: I figured he’d have chips.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: What if he doesn’t? What are we gonna eat it with?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Celery? Spoons? I don’t know. I didn’t have to bring anything. Across the street, Denny steps out his front door and wav to them as they approach.

dialogues.speaker: DENNY
dialogues.text: Hey. You found the pl--

dialogues.speaker: BOOM
dialogues.text: An ENORMOUS EXPLOSION tears through the house, engulfing Denny in a FIREBALL and RIPPING HIM TO SHREDS! The windows of Kurt’s car SHATTER. Car alarms go off. Nic Kurt and Dale scream and drop to the ground as debris rai down around them. They hold their ears which are ringing from the blast.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: What the fuck?!!

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Jesus!

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: He blew up! Denny blew up!

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Are you guys okay?!

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: What?! I can’t hear you!

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: What did you say?!  58.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: I can’t hear!

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: What?! As NEIGHBORS begin to come outside to see what happened, and Kurt suddenly notice something on Dale. They look horrified.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: Dale, your shoulder! A FLESHY MOUND of some sort has landed on Dale’s shoulder

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: (still deaf) Huh?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: What is that?

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: I’m not sure. Is that Denny’s chin?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Looks more like an elbow.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: What are you guys saying?!

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: (peering closer) Oh god. I think it’s his ball sack.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: No! Can't be. Dale looks at his shoulder and reacts.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Agh! What is that?! Get it off! He frantically wiggles his shoulder, trying to knock off unidentified body part.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fire trucks and police cars surround the now smoldering remains of the house.  59. Nick, Kurt and Dale, wrapped in blankets, are being treat for cuts and scratches at an ambulance. DETECTIVE HAGAN approaches.

dialogues.speaker: HAGAN
dialogues.text: Excuse me, gentlemen. I wonder if I can get a-- (recognizing them) Aw, shit. Not you clowns again.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Detective. We know who did this.

dialogues.speaker: HAGAN
dialogues.text: What do you mean, you know who did this? Fire department says it was an accidental gas leak.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: It was no accident.

dialogues.speaker: HAGAN
dialogues.text: Is that right? How come every time someone dies in front of their house, you assholes aren’t far away?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Just hear us out. We were coming to meet with the victim because we were all scammed by the same loan shark.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: We got venture capital from him and now he wants it all back or he’s gonna kill us.

dialogues.speaker: HAGAN
dialogues.text: What the hell did you need venture capital for?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: For our Shower Buddy.

dialogues.speaker: KURT
dialogues.text: (off Hagan’s confusion) It’s an adjustable showerhead that dispenses soap, shampoo and conditioner with the water.

dialogues.speaker: HAGAN
dialogues.text: You three came up with this? (they nod) That’s not a bad idea.  60.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Thank you. Nickurdale is very proud of it.

dialogues.speaker: HAGAN
dialogues.text: (shocked) Who's proud of it?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Nickurdale.

dialogues.speaker: HAGAN
dialogues.text: Nigger Dale?!
